column4: it's sudo fdisk -l. and it shows you the partition table. df -h will show you free space.
why not use sox?
what is sox?
i can't seem to get any program to read the disc. I have tried rhythmbox, sound juicer, and k3b
Sound eXchange... its an extreamly powerful tool
what is the disk your trying to read?
it's a very old scratched audio cd, a previously burnt disc not a commercially bought one.
sudo aptitude install sox will put sox on your system, and then you can use sox with the --parinioa flag too read the cd... as long as there are some fragments readable, you should get output

i did sudo aptitude install sox and it didn't find anything? I have all repo's enabled in jaunty? would you have a command to run for using sox because I am not sure how to configure sound juicer or anything else on how to use it with sox.
you dont use a GUI with sox, its purely used through CLI
oops, sox is installed by default... open a terminal and type man sox
ok

WOW. that's the biggest man page I have ever opened. also, there are no examples. i think I am just going to use dd and then use a nautilus script to convert the music to mp3 and fill out the tags using amarok tag guesser.
dd states that there is no Medium found.
sox -d /dev/cdrom -t wav /path/to/where/you/want
WOW. no medium found. it's useless. the cd is ruined I guess.
yea.. sorry
thanks for helping me though.
your welcome, sorrry your CD is destroyed
im a re-re... try sox -r 44100 -d -t cdda /path/to/where/you/like/music
some progress. here's what it returned. sox formats: can't open output file `/var/lib/mythtv/tmp/': Is a directory
i.. really.. need.. coffee before trying to help people, lol, try cdparinioa as a command
some progress. here's what it returned. sox formats: can't open output file `/var/lib/mythtv/tmp/': Is a directory
